What Is Railcar Securement Welding?

Railcar securement welding is field welding performed to stabilize and restrain heavy cargo during rail transport. This is common in:

  • Transformer moves
  • Industrial equipment shipments
  • Oversized components
  • Port load-outs
  • Rail yard staging operations

Securement typically includes welding:

  • Restraint tabs
  • Stops
  • Clips
  • Plates
  • Brackets
  • Blocking attachments

All based on a securement plan provided by the logistics or engineering team.

This work is almost always sequence-sensitive and time-critical, especially at active ports or terminals.

The 5 Biggest Causes of Load-Out Delays

In real-world port and rail environments, these are the most common failure points:

1. Poor Fit-Up

Improper alignment leads to grinding, re-fit, and re-weld work right before departure.

2. Incorrect Restraint Placement

If tabs, stops, or plates don‚Äôt match the securement plan, inspectors or supervisors may require correction.

3. Rushed Surface Prep

Contamination or poor prep can create weak attachments that must be redone.

4. Sequence Conflicts

Welding done at the wrong time can interfere with rigging steps, blocking access or delaying crane movements.

5. Lack of Coordination

If welding is not aligned with crane, transport, and terminal leadership, downtime increases.

Railcar securement welding is not just about making welds ‚Äî it‚Äôs about protecting schedule.

entry.title: RTU Curb Welding Explained: Why Certified Mobile Welders Are Critical for Commercial HVAC Installations

link.title: RTU Curb Welding Explained: Why Certified Mobile Welders Are Critical for Commercial HVAC Installations

entry.content:
When commercial HVAC systems are installed on rooftops, one critical component determines whether the system is safe, code-compliant, and structurally sound: the RTU curb weld.

RTU (Rooftop Unit) curbs must be welded correctly to handle wind loads, vibration, structural movement, and long-term exposure to harsh weather. Poor welding can lead to roof leaks, structural failure, failed inspections, and costly rework.

In this guide, we break down RTU curb welding explained, why it matters, and why hiring an AWS-certified mobile welder is essential for commercial construction and HVAC projects across Hampton Roads and beyond.

What Is RTU Curb Welding?

An RTU curb is a raised structural frame mounted on a roof to support HVAC rooftop units. The curb must be securely welded to steel roof decking, structural beams, or support frames.

RTU curb welding typically involves:

  • Structural steel welding to roof framing
  • Welding curb frames to steel supports
  • Reinforcing connections and brackets
  • Sealing welds to prevent water intrusion
  • Compliance with AWS D1.1 structural welding standards

Because RTU curbs directly impact structural integrity and weatherproofing, welding must be performed by qualified professionals‚Äînot general labor or HVAC installers alone.

If you‚Äôre searching for a mobile welder near me for RTU curb installation, experience with commercial and structural welding is non-negotiable.

Why RTU Curb Welding Requires a Certified Mobile Welder

RTU curb welding is not just fabrication‚Äîit‚Äôs structural work performed in the field under real-world conditions.

A certified mobile welding contractor ensures:

1) Structural Load Compliance

RTU curbs must withstand:

  • Wind uplift forces
  • Equipment vibration
  • Roof movement and thermal expansion
  • Seismic and code load requirements

Improper welds can cause structural failure or equipment displacement.

2) AWS D1.1 Structural Welding Standards

Commercial RTU curb welds often fall under AWS D1.1 requirements, meaning weld quality, joint design, and inspection readiness are critical.

3) Inspection-Ready Work

Many commercial projects require:

  • Visual inspection
  • Third-party inspection
  • Contractor QA/QC documentation

A professional welding subcontractor ensures welds pass inspection the first time.

4) On-Site Field Welding Expertise

Unlike shop fabrication, RTU curb welding happens on active rooftops with limited access, safety risks, and coordination with HVAC contractors.

That‚Äôs where a fully equipped mobile welding rig makes the difference.

RTU Curb Welding in Commercial Construction & Retail Build-Outs

RTU curb welding is common in:

  • Retail build-outs
  • Commercial renovations
  • Warehouses and distribution centers
  • Restaurants and shopping centers
  • Office buildings
  • Industrial facilities

For contractors managing tenant improvements or retail build-outs, partnering with a reliable welding subcontractor reduces risk, delays, and liability.

Common RTU Curb Welding Mistakes (and How to Avoid Them)

Many failures in RTU curb installations come from shortcuts or inexperienced welders.

entry.title: Welding Requirements for DOT Projects (AWS D1.1 Explained)

link.title: Welding Requirements for DOT Projects (AWS D1.1 Explained)

entry.content:
If you do any work tied to roadways, bridges, traffic structures, or public infrastructure, you already know the biggest risk isn‚Äôt ‚Äúcan we weld it?‚Äù‚Äîit‚Äôs will it pass inspection and stay compliant with DOT specs.

This guide breaks down how AWS D1.1 typically shows up on DOT jobs, when DOT work actually requires bridge-specific code (AWS D1.5), and what documentation + execution standards are most often expected in the field.

For DOT and infrastructure support in Hampton Roads and surrounding regions, see our DOT page here: Kings Mobile Welding ‚Äì DOT & Infrastructure ‚Üí https://www.kingsmobilewelding.com/industries/DOT-Infrastructure/

First: DOT welding isn‚Äôt ‚Äúone code‚Äù

Most DOT projects are governed by a stack of requirements:

  • Contract documents (plans/specs, special provisions, notes)
  • State DOT standard specs (ex: VDOT specs for Virginia projects)
  • National references (AASHTO specs and AWS structural welding codes)
  • Project QC/QA and inspection requirements

On bridges and primary structural steel, DOT work commonly points to the AASHTO/AWS Bridge Welding Code (AWS D1.5) rather than AWS D1.1. The FHWA‚Äôs Bridge Welding Reference Manual specifically explains how highway structures rely on AASHTO/AWS D1.5 and how it relates to AWS D1.1.

Bottom line:

  • AWS D1.1 is the general ‚Äústructural steel‚Äù code used across many industries.
  • AWS D1.5 is the bridge-focused code used for welded bridges/components designed to AASHTO/AREMA requirements.

And at the federal level, FHWA regulations list standards that include AASHTO/AWS D1.5 and AWS D1.4 (rebar) among the recognized references for highway-related standards.

Where AWS D1.1 shows up on DOT projects

Even when the project is ‚ÄúDOT,‚Äù not everything is bridge code. AWS D1.1 is commonly used for:

  • Highway-related structural steel that is not part of a bridge superstructure (project-specific‚Äîalways verify)
  • Miscellaneous steel packages on DOT jobs
  • Temporary works and support frames (if allowed by specs)
  • Field modifications/repairs to structural items that are governed by D1.1 in the contract
  • Fabrication or site welding on structures that fall under general structural steel requirements

Also, DOT work often involves other AWS codes depending on the material:

  • AWS D1.4 is used for reinforcing steel welding when permitted by the design/specs.

When it‚Äôs NOT AWS D1.1: bridge work often triggers AWS D1.5

If you‚Äôre welding on:

  • bridge girders / bridge components
  • bridge splices
  • structural bridge repairs governed by bridge specs
  • bridge fabrication requirements called out in DOT documents

‚Ä¶you‚Äôll very often be under AWS D1.5, not D1.1. DOT training/inspection materials commonly reference AASHTO/AWS D1.5 for bridge welding conformance.

Tip: The fastest way to get burned on DOT work is assuming ‚ÄúAWS D1.1 certified‚Äù automatically equals ‚Äúbridge compliant.‚Äù D1.1 is a big deal‚Äîbut bridge specs can be different (procedures, acceptance criteria, inspector expectations, etc.).

The DOT inspection mindset: ‚ÄúShow me the paperwork, then show me the weld‚Äù

On DOT jobs, the weld itself is only half the battle. The other half is proving you had control of:

1) Welding procedures: WPS (and sometimes PQR)

A WPS (Welding Procedure Specification) is the document the welder follows to produce code-compliant welds.

In AWS D1.1, many contractors use prequalified WPS (when the joint details, process, base metal group, filler, etc. meet the code‚Äôs prequalification limits). If you don‚Äôt meet prequal rules, you typically need procedure qualification testing (a PQR) to prove the procedure works.

What inspectors/GCs commonly want on DOT work:

  • The WPS on site (current revision, signed, legible)
  • Proof the procedure is prequalified or qualified by testing (as required)

2) Welder performance qualification (WPQ)

Even with a solid WPS, DOT/GCs will typically require proof the welder is qualified for:

  • the process (SMAW/FCAW/GMAW, etc.)
  • the position (1G/2G/3G/4G‚Ä¶)
  • the joint type and thickness range (per code/spec)

3) Material and filler control

Expect attention to:

  • base metal identification (including coatings like galvanizing, when applicable)
  • electrode/filler classification and storage/conditioning as required by project specs
  • preheat/interpass requirements as written in the WPS (and sometimes contract notes)

4) Inspection + acceptance criteria

DOT work frequently requires a documented inspection pathway (visual inspection always, and NDT when specified). The ‚Äúacceptance‚Äù criteria will be whatever the contract cites (D1.1 vs D1.5 vs special provisions).

What ‚ÄúAWS D1.1 explained‚Äù means in the field (plain English)

Here‚Äôs the practical way to think about AWS D1.1 on real jobs:

  • D1.1 tells you how to make structural welds that are acceptable under the code (procedures, qualification, workmanship, inspection).
  • You still have to follow the job‚Äôs drawings and spec notes (D1.1 doesn‚Äôt override project requirements).
  • Your WPS is the rulebook your welder actually follows on the jobsite. If you can‚Äôt produce it, you‚Äôre immediately on defense.
  • Prequalified WPS saves time‚Äîbut only if your joint/process variables stay inside the prequalification limits.

DOT contractor checklist: what to have ready before you mobilize

If you want to look ‚Äúinspection-ready‚Äù (and win more DOT-related work), show up with:

  • WPS packet (project-relevant procedures)
  • Welder qualifications (WPQ continuity if required)
  • Calibration/condition evidence when applicable (machines, ovens, etc. per project)
  • COI + safety docs (GC onboarding requirements)
  • Jobsite execution plan (access, traffic control coordination if needed, lift plan if required)
  • NDT coordination plan if the contract calls for MT/PT/UT/RT

This is exactly how we approach field support as a subcontractor: Welding Subcontractor Services ‚Üí https://www.kingsmobilewelding.com/services/welding-subcontractor/ Structural Steel Welding (Field Welding Support) ‚Üí https://www.kingsmobilewelding.com/services/structural-steel-welding/

Common DOT welding scenarios (and what usually matters most)

Field splices / structural modifications

  • Correct joint prep and fit-up
  • WPS matches the joint and position
  • Heat input/preheat control (per WPS/spec)
  • Visual acceptance + NDT if required

Galvanized or coated steel repairs

  • Coating removal in weld zone (per spec and good practice)
  • Fume control and PPE
  • Repair coating requirements after weld (often governed by project coating spec, not welding code)

Rebar welding (when allowed)

  • Often governed by AWS D1.4 (not D1.1).
  • Many DOT designs restrict rebar welding except for approved details‚Äîalways verify.

Why primes and GCs care: risk, schedule, and closeout

DOT jobs are schedule-driven and paper-driven. A single failed weld or missing document can cause:

  • repair cycles
  • inspector hold points
  • delays to subsequent trades
  • payment delays during closeout

Our goal is simple: show up prepared, coordinate cleanly, and deliver welds that pass the first time‚Äîespecially on infrastructure scopes where downtime is expensive.

Kings Mobile Welding: DOT-ready field welding support in Hampton Roads

If you‚Äôre a DOT contractor, civil GC, pile driver, or steel erector and need reliable field welding support, we‚Äôre built for that workflow.

Start here: DOT & Infrastructure ‚Üí https://www.kingsmobilewelding.com/industries/DOT-Infrastructure/ Structural Steel ‚Üí https://www.kingsmobilewelding.com/services/structural-steel-welding/ Subcontractor Support ‚Üí https://www.kingsmobilewelding.com/services/welding-subcontractor/

Areas we serve (quick links)

  • Hampton, VA ‚Üí https://www.kingsmobilewelding.com/areas/hampton-va
  • Norfolk, VA ‚Üí https://www.kingsmobilewelding.com/areas/norfolk-va
  • Virginia Beach, VA ‚Üí https://www.kingsmobilewelding.com/areas/virginia-beach-va
  • Chesapeake, VA ‚Üí https://www.kingsmobilewelding.com/areas/chesapeake-va
  • Suffolk, VA ‚Üí https://www.kingsmobilewelding.com/areas/suffolk-va

FAQ: DOT welding requirements (quick answers)

Is AWS D1.1 the DOT welding code? Sometimes‚Äîbut many bridge-related scopes are governed by AWS D1.5 (bridge welding code) and DOT specs may also invoke other standards depending on the item.

What‚Äôs the main difference between D1.1 and D1.5? D1.1 is the general structural steel code; D1.5 is specifically written for welded bridges and bridge components designed to AASHTO/AREMA requirements.

Do I need a WPS on site for DOT work? In practice, yes‚ÄîGCs/inspectors commonly expect the WPS and welder qualifications to be available, especially on structural scopes.
